title: A recurrent regulatory change underlying altered expression and Wnt response of the stickleback armor plates gene <italic>EDA</italic>
abstract: Armor plate changes in sticklebacks are a classic example of repeated adaptive evolution. Previous studies identified <italic>ectodysplasin (EDA)</italic> gene as the major locus controlling recurrent plate loss in freshwater fish, though the causative DNA alterations were not known. Here we show that freshwater <italic>EDA</italic> alleles have <italic>cis</italic>-acting regulatory changes that reduce expression in developing plates and spines. An identical T → G base pair change is found in <italic>EDA</italic> enhancers of divergent low-plated fish. Recreation of the T → G change in a marine enhancer strongly reduces expression in posterior armor plates. Bead implantation and cell culture experiments show that Wnt signaling strongly activates the marine <italic>EDA</italic> enhancer, and the freshwater T → G change reduces Wnt responsiveness. Thus parallel evolution of low-plated sticklebacks has occurred through a shared DNA regulatory change, which reduces the sensitivity of an <italic>EDA</italic> enhancer to Wnt signaling, and alters expression in developing armor plates while preserving expression in other tissues.
